explanations.summary: Left ventricle subendocardium blood flow is GREATEST during DIASTOLE. During systole, high intramyocardial pressure (especially in inner layers) compresses vessels and reduces/stops flow. Subendocardium is NOT avascular - it has coronary supply.

whyCorrect.a: Subendocardial blood flow is much larger during DIASTOLE because: (1) During systole, left ventricle wall tension compresses coronary vessels; (2) Subendocardium experiences the highest compression being closest to ventricular cavity; (3) During diastole, muscle relaxes and vessels open fully.

whyIncorrect.b: The subendocardium IS vascularized by coronary arteries. It is NOT supplied by ventricular blood - there's no direct diffusion from chambers to myocardium in adults.
whyIncorrect.c: Flow is NOT larger during systole - it's actually minimal or reversed due to high intramyocardial pressure compressing vessels.
whyIncorrect.d: Flow is NOT equal - there's dramatic phasic variation with diastole >> systole in the left ventricle.

explanations.summary: Subendocardial blood flow in left ventricle is GREATEST during DIASTOLE due to systolic compression of coronary vessels by high intramyocardial pressure. The inner wall layers experience most compression.

whyCorrect.a: Blood flow is much larger during diastole than systole. During systole, high left ventricular pressure (120+ mmHg) compresses intramural vessels, especially in subendocardium. During diastole, ventricular muscle relaxes and coronary perfusion occurs.

whyIncorrect.b: Wrong on two counts: (1) Flow is NOT larger during systole - it's reduced; (2) Subendocardium IS perfused by coronary arteries, not chamber blood.
whyIncorrect.c: Flow is REDUCED during systole due to compression of coronary vessels by contracting myocardium.
whyIncorrect.d: Flow is dramatically unequal - predominantly diastolic in the left ventricle due to high systolic wall tension.

explanations.summary: Coronary flow depends on: diastolic BP (perfusion pressure), heart rate (determines diastole duration), right atrial pressure (downstream pressure), diastole duration (perfusion time), and posture (hydrostatic effects). NOT intrathoracic pressure directly.

whyCorrect.a: Diastolic blood pressure is the main determinant of coronary perfusion pressure since flow occurs predominantly during diastole.
whyCorrect.b: Heart rate affects coronary flow by determining the duration of diastole - higher HR = shorter diastole = less perfusion time.
whyCorrect.c: Right atrial pressure affects coronary venous drainage (coronary sinus drains to RA). Higher RAP impedes drainage.
whyCorrect.d: Duration of diastole directly determines how much time is available for coronary perfusion.
whyCorrect.f: Posture affects coronary flow through hydrostatic pressure effects and autonomic reflexes.

whyIncorrect.e: Intrathoracic pressure has minimal direct effect on coronary flow. It affects venous return but not coronary perfusion specifically.

explanations.summary: Left coronary flow: (1) IS greatest during DIASTOLE (systolic compression), (2) IS regulated by myocardial O2 consumption (metabolic control). Flow DOES depend on BP and is only ~5% of CO, not 10%.

whyCorrect.b: Left coronary flow is greatest during DIASTOLE because systolic contraction compresses the intramural vessels. Most perfusion occurs when the ventricle relaxes.
whyCorrect.d: Coronary flow is regulated mainly by myocardial O2 consumption through metabolic vasodilation. Adenosine is a key mediator - increased O2 demand causes vasodilation.

whyIncorrect.a: Coronary flow absolutely DOES depend on arterial blood pressure - diastolic pressure is the driving pressure for coronary perfusion.
whyIncorrect.c: Coronary blood flow is about 4-5% of cardiac output at rest (250 mL/min out of 5 L/min), not 10%.

explanations.summary: Cardiac work has THREE components: (1) PRESSURE work (generating pressure against resistance), (2) VOLUME work (ejecting stroke volume), (3) ACCELERATION work (accelerating blood mass). Pressure work consumes most O2.

whyCorrect.b: Total cardiac work = Pressure work + Volume work + Acceleration work. Pressure work (isovolumetric contraction against afterload) is largest and most O2-consuming. Volume work moves blood. Acceleration work gives kinetic energy to ejected blood.

whyIncorrect.c: Incomplete - missing pressure work, which is actually the largest component.

explanations.summary: Left coronary artery flow: GREATEST during DIASTOLE (systolic compression impedes flow), regulated mainly by myocardial O2 consumption (metabolic control via adenosine). Does depend on BP, and is ~5% of CO.

whyCorrect.b: Coronary flow is regulated mainly by myocardial O2 consumption. Increased metabolic demand releases adenosine and other vasodilators, causing coronary vasodilation to match flow to demand.
whyCorrect.c: Left coronary flow is greatest during DIASTOLE. During systole, the contracting left ventricle compresses intramural coronary vessels, reducing or stopping flow.

whyIncorrect.a: Coronary flow DOES depend on arterial blood pressure. Diastolic pressure is the perfusion pressure for coronary circulation.
whyIncorrect.d: Coronary blood flow is approximately 4-5% of cardiac output (about 250 mL/min), not 10%.

explanations.summary: Left ventricle myocardium receives coronary blood supply predominantly during DIASTOLE. Systolic contraction compresses intramural vessels, reducing or stopping flow. This is unique to left ventricle due to high systolic pressures.

whyCorrect.b: Left ventricular myocardium receives blood predominantly during DIASTOLE when the muscle is relaxed and coronary vessels are open. Systolic contraction generates high intramyocardial pressure that compresses coronary vessels.

whyIncorrect.a: Isometric (isovolumetric) contraction is early systole when ventricular pressure rises sharply - this actually REDUCES coronary flow by compressing vessels.
whyIncorrect.c: Flow is NOT continuous - there's marked phasic variation with very little flow during systole and most flow during diastole.
whyIncorrect.d: Rapid ejection phase is mid-systole with high wall tension - coronary flow is minimal during this phase.
